publicationstmt.publisher: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

seriesstmt.titleproper: Guides to the Collections in the Archive of Folk Culture

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: 1992 Neptune Plaza Concert Series Collection 1992

repository.label: Location
repository.corpname: Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center Library of Congress

physdesc.label: Extent (Sound Recordings)
physdesc.extent: 7 sound tape reels : analog: 7 1⁄2 ips, 2 track, stereo; 10 in.

physdesc.label: Extent (Sound Recordings)
physdesc.extent: 1 sound tape reel : analog: 7 1⁄2 ips, 2 track, stereo; 7 in.

physdesc.label: Extent (Graphic Materials)
physdesc.extent: 28 photographic prints : black and white, color ; 8x10 in. and smaller.

physdesc.label: Extent (Graphic Materials)
physdesc.extent: 516 photographs: on 23 contact sheets, black and white.

did.abstract: Manuscript materials, sound recordings, photographs, and moving images documenting the performance of Puerto Rican folk music; Tennesse old-time music; folk music from Veracruz, Mexico; dances of the Tewa Indians from the Santa Clara Pueblo; Irish folk dance and music; gospel music; and bluegrass music recorded live outdoors on Neptune Plaza in front of the Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, at concerts from April through September 1992, sponsored by the American Folklife Center. Some concerts were recorded for broadcast on WAMU-FM, hosted by Dick Spottswood. Manuscripts include some correspondence and program flyers autographed by the performers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The 1992 Neptune Plaza Concert Series Collection consists of manuscript and print materials, sound recordings, graphic materials, and moving images that document the 1992 concert series sponsored by the American Folklife Center. The annual series, which began in 1977, features the presentation of folk traditions from many cultures. The concerts take place on the Neptune Plaza at the front of the Jefferson Building of the Library of Congress between April and September. Adverse weather conditions sometimes force the concerts indoors.

The 1992 season consisted of the following:
Date Performers Place of Origin Subject
April 23 Edwin Colón Zayas y su Taller Campesino Puerto Rico Puerto Rican traditional string music
May 21 Ralph Blizard and the New Southern Ramblers Tennessee Old-time music and step dancing
June 5 Los Pregoneros del Puerto California Veracruz harp music
June 25 Santa Clara Pueblo Dancers New Mexico Tewa music and dance
July 16 Donna Long and Brendan Mulvihill Maryland and Ireland Irish Traditional music and dance
August 20 Helen Smith and the Angels of Faith District of Columbia Gospel music
September 10 Everett Lilly and Clear Creek Crossin' West Virginia Bluegrass music

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: Documentation created and accessioned by the American Folklife Center in 1992.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject and listed alphabetically therein.

controlaccess.head: Organizations
controlaccess.corpname: Archive of Folk Culture (Library of Congress)
Edwin Colón Zayas y su Taller Campesino (Musical group) performer.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Listening and viewing access to the collection is unrestricted. Duplication of the materials requires prior permission of the Center and may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 1992 Neptune Plaza Concert Series Collection (AFC 1992/001), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

did.unittitle: Series I: PRINT MATERIALS
Archive of Folk Culture Administrative Materials.

scopecontent.p: The collection guide (this document), an article describing the Neptune Plaza Concert Series, press releases on the 1992 concert lineup, and a three and one-half inch computer diskette containing logs of the concerts (all logs are available in hard copy in the individual concert folders).

row.entry: The Tewa people from the Santa Clara Pueblo in New Mexico present the Buffalo dance. Background and narration provided by the governor of the pueblo, Walter Dasheno. Print material, photographs, and slides: folders 15-17, envelope 7; sound recording: AFC 1992/001:SR7; videotape: AFC 1992/001:V7.

Irish music and dance presented by Donna Long, Brendan Mulvihill, and Regan Wick. Wick, a champion step dancer, performs a set dance, a reel, and a hornpipe, as well as an a cappella piece. Print material and photographs: folders 20-22, envelope 8; sound recordings: AFC 1992/001:SR8-9; videotape: AFC 1992/001:V4.
Ralph Blizard and the New Southern Ramblers

Long-time fiddler Ralph Blizard, known for his unique fiddling style called "Tennessee Long Bow," presents Appalachian music with members of the New Southern Ramblers, Phil Jamison and John Lilly. Jamison and Lilly, both former members of the Green Grass Cloggers, demonstrate individual clogging styles. Print material and photographs: folders 6-9; sound recordings: AFC 1992/001:SR4-5; videotape: AFC 1992/001:V2.
